articles.headline: U.S. Limits Demands on Google
articles.snippet: After the Justice Department drastically reduced its request for information from Google, a federal judge said on Tuesday that he intended to approve at least part of that request.     The government first subpoenaed Web data from Google last Augu...
articles.abstract: After the Justice Department drastically reduced its request for information from Google, a federal judge said on Tuesday that he intended to approve at least part of that request.     The government first subpoenaed Web data from Google last August, as part of its defense of an online pornography law.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 14 - After the Justice Department drastically reduced its request for information from Google, a federal judge said on Tuesday that he intended to approve at least part of that request.

articles.headline: U.S. Investigates Pension Fund at Northwest Air
articles.snippet: The Labor Department is investigating whether Northwest Airlines systematically shortchanged its employee pension fund over three years, then avoided having to make a $65 million payment to the fund by filing for bankruptcy protection just one day...
articles.abstract: The Labor Department is investigating whether Northwest Airlines systematically shortchanged its employee pension fund over three years, then avoided having to make a $65 million payment to the fund by filing for bankruptcy protection just one day before the payment was due.     The government has subpoenaed voluminous and detailed information from Northwest going back to January 2002, when both the airline and its pension fund faced severe financial pressures after the terrorist attacks of 2001 and the bursting of the technology bubble in the stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Labor Department is investigating whether Northwest Airlines systematically shortchanged its employee pension fund over three years, then avoided having to make a $65 million payment to the fund by filing for bankruptcy protection just one day before the payment was due.

articles.headline: Mike Wallace Says He Will Retire From '60 Minutes' in Spring
articles.snippet: When asked in an interview last April if he would ever consider retiring from the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' Mike Wallace said that he planned to do so only ''when my toes turn up.''     ''Well,'' Mr. Wallace said, amending that statement in...
articles.abstract: When asked in an interview last April if he would ever consider retiring from the CBS News program ''60 Minutes,'' Mike Wallace said that he planned to do so only ''when my toes turn up.''     ''Well,'' Mr. Wallace said, amending that statement in an interview yesterday, ''they're just beginning to curl a trifle.''
articles.lead_paragraph: When asked in an interview last April if he would ever consider retiring from the CBS News program "60 Minutes," Mike Wallace said that he planned to do so only "when my toes turn up."

articles.headline: Many Utilities Collect for Taxes They Never Pay
articles.snippet: Many electric utility companies across the nation are collecting billions of dollars from their customers for corporate income taxes, then keeping the money rather than sending it to the government.     The practice is legal in most states. The co...
articles.abstract: Many electric utility companies across the nation are collecting billions of dollars from their customers for corporate income taxes, then keeping the money rather than sending it to the government.     The practice is legal in most states. The companies say it is smart business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many electric utility companies across the nation are collecting billions of dollars from their customers for corporate income taxes, then keeping the money rather than sending it to the government.

articles.headline: Bank Deal's Payout Plan Questioned
articles.snippet: The compensation adviser behind an estimated $135 million payout to the chief executive of North Fork Bancorporation  has also received fees for other services from the bank in recent years, according to regulatory filings.      The other business...
articles.abstract: The compensation adviser behind an estimated $135 million payout to the chief executive of North Fork Bancorporation  has also received fees for other services from the bank in recent years, according to regulatory filings.      The other business dealings the adviser, Mercer Human Resources Consulting, has had with North Fork raise questions among corporate governance experts about the pay recommendations it made to the bank's board, which has a duty to company shareholders, not to management.
articles.lead_paragraph: The compensation adviser behind an estimated $135 million payout to the chief executive of North Fork Bancorporation has also received fees for other services from the bank in recent years, according to regulatory filings.

articles.headline: Iowa's Residency Rules Drive Sex Offenders Underground
articles.snippet: Restrictions on where sex offenders can live have rendered some of them homeless, and many have simply vanished from sight.
articles.abstract: Restrictions on where sex offenders can live have rendered some of them homeless, and many have simply vanished from sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa â€” One cornfield beyond the trim white farmhouse where the Boland family lives and a road sign warns, "Watch for children and dogs," is a faded motel.

articles.headline: In Iran, Dissenting Voices Riseon Its Leaders' Nuclear Strategy
articles.snippet: Just weeks ago, the Iranian government's combative approach toward building a nuclear program produced rare public displays of unity here. Now, while the top leaders remain resolute in their course, cracks are opening both inside and outside the c...
articles.abstract: Just weeks ago, the Iranian government's combative approach toward building a nuclear program produced rare public displays of unity here. Now, while the top leaders remain resolute in their course, cracks are opening both inside and outside the circles of power over the issue.      Some people in powerful positions have begun to insist that the confrontational tactics of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad have been backfiring, making it harder instead of easier for Iran to develop a nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, March 14 - Just weeks ago, the Iranian government's combative approach toward building a nuclear program produced rare public displays of unity here. Now, while the top leaders remain resolute in their course, cracks are opening both inside and outside the circles of power over the issue.

articles.headline: Raising the Bar in the Aircraft Wars
articles.snippet: Airbus is in the late stages of negotiations to build an assembly line for its A320 passenger plane in China, a landmark deal that would significantly lift its prospects for business there.      Producing European planes in China would open a new ...
articles.abstract: Airbus is in the late stages of negotiations to build an assembly line for its A320 passenger plane in China, a landmark deal that would significantly lift its prospects for business there.      Producing European planes in China would open a new front in the battle between Airbus and Boeing for the world's next great aviation market, as well as underscore the growing role of state enterprises in the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, March 14 - Airbus is in the late stages of negotiations to build an assembly line for its A320 passenger plane in China, a landmark deal that would significantly lift its prospects for business there.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Who's Afraid of Banking at Wal-Mart?
articles.snippet: IMAGINE that Wal-Mart announced it was going to open a new kind of store, one that would have all the benefits of the chain's low prices without a lot of the collateral damage.     Shoppers who went to this store would save money, and they would b...
articles.abstract: IMAGINE that Wal-Mart announced it was going to open a new kind of store, one that would have all the benefits of the chain's low prices without a lot of the collateral damage.     Shoppers who went to this store would save money, and they would be able to choose from a wider variety of products than they now do. But the store would not put mom-and-pop hardware stores out of business, and it would not steal jobs from unionized supermarket workers. It would mainly hurt mammoth corporations and Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE that Wal-Mart announced it was going to open a new kind of store, one that would have all the benefits of the chain's low prices without a lot of the collateral damage.

articles.headline: Iowa's Residency Rules Drive Sex Offenders Underground
articles.snippet: One cornfield beyond the trim white farmhouse where the Boland family lives and a road sign warns, ''Watch for children and dogs,'' is a faded motel.      For years a layover for budget-conscious motorists and construction crews, the motel has lat...
articles.abstract: One cornfield beyond the trim white farmhouse where the Boland family lives and a road sign warns, ''Watch for children and dogs,'' is a faded motel.      For years a layover for budget-conscious motorists and construction crews, the motel has lately become a disquieting symbol of what has gone wrong with Iowa's crackdown on sexual offenders of children. With just 24 rooms, the motel, the Ced-Rel, was home to 26 registered sex offenders by the start of March.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - One cornfield beyond the trim white farmhouse where the Boland family lives and a road sign warns, "Watch for children and dogs," is a faded motel.

articles.headline: Israelis Seize 6 in Raid on Prison in the West Bank
articles.snippet: With tanks, bulldozers and helicopters, Israeli military forces besieged a Palestinian prison here for 10 hours on Tuesday before seizing six Palestinian inmates. The men had been held for four years in an unusual arrangement that involved the Uni...
articles.abstract: With tanks, bulldozers and helicopters, Israeli military forces besieged a Palestinian prison here for 10 hours on Tuesday before seizing six Palestinian inmates. The men had been held for four years in an unusual arrangement that involved the United States and Britain.     The confrontation began in the morning and lasted until Israel captured the men after nightfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERICHO, West Bank, March 14 - With tanks, bulldozers and helicopters, Israeli military forces besieged a Palestinian prison here for 10 hours on Tuesday before seizing six Palestinian inmates. The men had been held for four years in an unusual arrangement that involved the United States and Britain.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Greg Myre

articles.headline: Lawyer Thrust Into Spotlight After Misstep in Terror Case
articles.snippet: In a city of lawyers, Carla J. Martin has become the most talked-about lawyer in town.      Ms. Martin, an obscure official in the counsel's office at the Transportation Security Administration, now appears to bear responsibility for undercutting ...
articles.abstract: In a city of lawyers, Carla J. Martin has become the most talked-about lawyer in town.      Ms. Martin, an obscure official in the counsel's office at the Transportation Security Administration, now appears to bear responsibility for undercutting the government's long-running effort to execute the only man tried in an American courtroom for involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 14 - In a city of lawyers, Carla J. Martin has become the most talked-about lawyer in town.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: 85 Bodies Found in Baghdad in Sectarian Strife
articles.snippet: The bodies of more than 85 executed men have surfaced across Baghdad in the past two days, in Sunni and Shiite neighborhoods, providing graphic proof, yet again, of sectarian mayhem.     Many bodies bore marks of torture -- badly beaten faces, gag...
articles.abstract: The bodies of more than 85 executed men have surfaced across Baghdad in the past two days, in Sunni and Shiite neighborhoods, providing graphic proof, yet again, of sectarian mayhem.     Many bodies bore marks of torture -- badly beaten faces, gagged mouths and rope burns around the neck -- though it remains unclear who is responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 14 - The bodies of more than 85 executed men have surfaced across Baghdad in the past two days, in Sunni and Shiite neighborhoods, providing graphic proof, yet again, of sectarian mayhem.
